Chapter 6.6:1: Let us go forward, then, to mature teaching and leave behind us the first lessons of the Christian message. We should not lay again the foundation of turning away from useless works and believing in God;

Chapter 6.6:2: of the teaching about baptisms and the laying on of hands; of the resurrection of the dead and the eternal judgment.

Chapter 6.6:3: Let us go forward! And this is what we will do, if God allows.

Chapter 6.6:4: For how can those who abandon their faith be brought back to repent again? They were once in God's light; they tasted heaven's gift and received their share of the Holy Spirit;

Chapter 6.6:5: they knew from experience that God's word is good, and they had felt the powers of the coming age.

Chapter 6.6:6: And then they abandoned their faith! It is impossible to bring them back to repent again, because they are again crucifying the Son of God and exposing him to public shame.

Chapter 6.6:7: God blesses the soil which drinks in the rain that often falls on it and which grows plants that are useful to those for whom it is cultivated.

Chapter 6.6:8: But if it grows thorns and weeds, it is worth nothing; it is in danger of being cursed by God and will be destroyed by fire.

Chapter 6.6:9: But even if we speak like this, dear friends, we feel sure about you. We know that you have the better blessings that belong to your salvation.

Chapter 6.6:10: God is not unfair. He will not forget the work you did or the love you showed for him in the help you gave and are still giving to other Christians.

Chapter 6.6:11: Our great desire is that each of you keep up your eagerness to the end, so that the things you hope for will come true.

Chapter 6.6:12: We do not want you to become lazy, but to be like those who believe and are patient, and so receive what God has promised.

Chapter 6.6:13: When God made his promise to Abraham, he made a vow to do what he had promised. Since there was no one greater than himself, he used his own name when he made his vow.

Chapter 6.6:14: He said, I promise you that I will bless you and give you many descendants.

Chapter 6.6:15: Abraham was patient, and so he received what God had promised.

Chapter 6.6:16: When we make a vow, we use the name of someone greater than ourselves, and the vow settles all arguments.

Chapter 6.6:17: To those who were to receive what he promised, God wanted to make it very clear that he would never change his purpose; so he added his vow to the promise.

Chapter 6.6:18: There are these two things, then, that cannot change and about which God cannot lie. So we who have found safety with him are greatly encouraged to hold firmly to the hope placed before us.

Chapter 6.6:19: We have this hope as an anchor for our lives. It is safe and sure, and goes through the curtain of the heavenly temple into the inner sanctuary.

Chapter 6.6:20: On our behalf Jesus has gone in there before us and has become a high priest forever, in the priestly order of Melchizedek.

Chapter 9.9:1: The first covenant had rules for worship and a place made for worship as well.

Chapter 9.9:2: A tent was put up, the outer one, which was called the Holy Place. In it were the lampstand and the table with the bread offered to God.

Chapter 9.9:3: Behind the second curtain was the tent called the Most Holy Place.

Chapter 9.9:4: In it were the gold altar for the burning of incense and the Covenant Box all covered with gold and containing the gold jar with the manna in it, Aaron's stick that had sprouted leaves, and the two stone tablets with the commandments written on them.

Chapter 9.9:5: Above the Box were the winged creatures representing God's presence, with their wings spread over the place where sins were forgiven. But now is not the time to explain everything in detail.

Chapter 9.9:6: This is how those things have been arranged. The priests go into the outer tent every day to perform their duties,

Chapter 9.9:7: but only the high priest goes into the inner tent, and he does so only once a year. He takes with him blood which he offers to God on behalf of himself and for the sins which the people have committed without knowing they were sinning.

Chapter 9.9:8: The Holy Spirit clearly teaches from all these arrangements that the way into the Most Holy Place has not yet been opened as long as the outer tent still stands.

Chapter 9.9:9: This is a symbol which points to the present time. It means that the offerings and animal sacrifices presented to God cannot make the worshiper's heart perfect,

Chapter 9.9:10: since they have to do only with food, drink, and various purification ceremonies. These are all outward rules, which apply only until the time when God will establish the new order.

Chapter 9.9:11: But Christ has already come as the High Priest of the good things that are already here. The tent in which he serves is greater and more perfect; it is not a tent made by human hands, that is, it is not a part of this created world.

Chapter 9.9:12: When Christ went through the tent and entered once and for all into the Most Holy Place, he did not take the blood of goats and bulls to offer as a sacrifice; rather, he took his own blood and obtained eternal salvation for us.

Chapter 9.9:13: The blood of goats and bulls and the ashes of a burnt calf are sprinkled on the people who are ritually unclean, and this purifies them by taking away their ritual impurity.

Chapter 9.9:14: Since this is true, how much more is accomplished by the blood of Christ! Through the eternal Spirit he offered himself as a perfect sacrifice to God. His blood will purify our consciences from useless rituals, so that we may serve the living God.

Chapter 9.9:15: For this reason Christ is the one who arranges a new covenant, so that those who have been called by God may receive the eternal blessings that God has promised. This can be done because there has been a death which sets people free from the wrongs they did while the first covenant was in effect.

Chapter 9.9:16: In the case of a will it is necessary to prove that the person who made it has died,

Chapter 9.9:17: for a will means nothing while the person who made it is alive; it goes into effect only after his death.

Chapter 9.9:18: That is why even the first covenant went into effect only with the use of blood.

Chapter 9.9:19: First, Moses proclaimed to the people all the commandments as set forth in the Law. Then he took the blood of bulls and goats, mixed it with water, and sprinkled it on the book of the Law and all the people, using a sprig of hyssop and some red wool.

Chapter 9.9:20: He said, This is the blood which seals the covenant that God has commanded you to obey.

Chapter 9.9:21: In the same way Moses also sprinkled the blood on the Sacred Tent and over all the things used in worship.

Chapter 9.9:22: Indeed, according to the Law almost everything is purified by blood, and sins are forgiven only if blood is poured out.

Chapter 9.9:23: Those things, which are copies of the heavenly originals, had to be purified in that way. But the heavenly things themselves require much better sacrifices.

Chapter 9.9:24: For Christ did not go into a Holy Place made by human hands, which was a copy of the real one. He went into heaven itself, where he now appears on our behalf in the presence of God.

Chapter 9.9:25: The Jewish high priest goes into the Most Holy Place every year with the blood of an animal. But Christ did not go in to offer himself many times,

Chapter 9.9:26: for then he would have had to suffer many times ever since the creation of the world. Instead, now when all ages of time are nearing the end, he has appeared once and for all, to remove sin through the sacrifice of himself.

Chapter 9.9:27: Everyone must die once, and after that be judged by God.

Chapter 9.9:28: In the same manner Christ also was offered in sacrifice once to take away the sins of many. He will appear a second time, not to deal with sin, but to save those who are waiting for him.

Chapter 11.11:1: To have faith is to be sure of the things we hope for, to be certain of the things we cannot see.

Chapter 11.11:2: It was by their faith that people of ancient times won God's approval.

Chapter 11.11:3: It is by faith that we understand that the universe was created by God's word, so that what can be seen was made out of what cannot be seen.

Chapter 11.11:4: It was faith that made Abel offer to God a better sacrifice than Cain's. Through his faith he won God's approval as a righteous man, because God himself approved of his gifts. By means of his faith Abel still speaks, even though he is dead.

Chapter 11.11:5: It was faith that kept Enoch from dying. Instead, he was taken up to God, and nobody could find him, because God had taken him up. The scripture says that before Enoch was taken up, he had pleased God.

Chapter 11.11:6: No one can please God without faith, for whoever comes to God must have faith that God exists and rewards those who seek him.

Chapter 11.11:7: It was faith that made Noah hear God's warnings about things in the future that he could not see. He obeyed God and built a boat in which he and his family were saved. As a result, the world was condemned, and Noah received from God the righteousness that comes by faith.

Chapter 11.11:8: It was faith that made Abraham obey when God called him to go out to a country which God had promised to give him. He left his own country without knowing where he was going.

Chapter 11.11:9: By faith he lived as a foreigner in the country that God had promised him. He lived in tents, as did Isaac and Jacob, who received the same promise from God.

Chapter 11.11:10: For Abraham was waiting for the city which God has designed and built, the city with permanent foundations.

Chapter 11.11:11: It was faith that made Abraham able to become a father, even though he was too old and Sarah herself could not have children. He trusted God to keep his promise.

Chapter 11.11:12: Though Abraham was practically dead, from this one man came as many descendants as there are stars in the sky, as many as the numberless grains of sand on the seashore.

Chapter 11.11:13: It was in faith that all these persons died. They did not receive the things God had promised, but from a long way off they saw them and welcomed them, and admitted openly that they were foreigners and refugees on earth.

Chapter 11.11:14: Those who say such things make it clear that they are looking for a country of their own.

Chapter 11.11:15: They did not keep thinking about the country they had left; if they had, they would have had the chance to return.

Chapter 11.11:16: Instead, it was a better country they longed for, the heavenly country. And so God is not ashamed for them to call him their God, because he has prepared a city for them.

Chapter 11.11:17: It was faith that made Abraham offer his son Isaac as a sacrifice when God put Abraham to the test. Abraham was the one to whom God had made the promise, yet he was ready to offer his only son as a sacrifice.

Chapter 11.11:18: God had said to him, It is through Isaac that you will have the descendants I promised.

Chapter 11.11:19: Abraham reckoned that God was able to raise Isaac from death—and, so to speak, Abraham did receive Isaac back from death.

Chapter 11.11:20: It was faith that made Isaac promise blessings for the future to Jacob and Esau.

Chapter 11.11:21: It was faith that made Jacob bless each of the sons of Joseph just before he died. He leaned on the top of his walking stick and worshiped God.

Chapter 11.11:22: It was faith that made Joseph, when he was about to die, speak of the departure of the Israelites from Egypt, and leave instructions about what should be done with his body.

Chapter 11.11:23: It was faith that made the parents of Moses hide him for three months after he was born. They saw that he was a beautiful child, and they were not afraid to disobey the king's order.

Chapter 11.11:24: It was faith that made Moses, when he had grown up, refuse to be called the son of the king's daughter.

Chapter 11.11:25: He preferred to suffer with God's people rather than to enjoy sin for a little while.

Chapter 11.11:26: He reckoned that to suffer scorn for the Messiah was worth far more than all the treasures of Egypt, for he kept his eyes on the future reward.

Chapter 11.11:27: It was faith that made Moses leave Egypt without being afraid of the king's anger. As though he saw the invisible God, he refused to turn back.

Chapter 11.11:28: It was faith that made him establish the Passover and order the blood to be sprinkled on the doors, so that the Angel of Death would not kill the first-born sons of the Israelites.

Chapter 11.11:29: It was faith that made the Israelites able to cross the Red Sea as if on dry land; when the Egyptians tried to do it, the water swallowed them up.

Chapter 11.11:30: It was faith that made the walls of Jericho fall down after the Israelites had marched around them for seven days.

Chapter 11.11:31: It was faith that kept the prostitute Rahab from being killed with those who disobeyed God, for she gave the Israelite spies a friendly welcome.

Chapter 11.11:32: Should I go on? There isn't enough time for me to speak of Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, David, Samuel, and the prophets.

Chapter 11.11:33: Through faith they fought whole countries and won. They did what was right and received what God had promised. They shut the mouths of lions,

Chapter 11.11:34: put out fierce fires, escaped being killed by the sword. They were weak, but became strong; they were mighty in battle and defeated the armies of foreigners.

Chapter 11.11:35: Through faith women received their dead relatives raised back to life. Others, refusing to accept freedom, died under torture in order to be raised to a better life.

Chapter 11.11:36: Some were mocked and whipped, and others were put in chains and taken off to prison.

Chapter 11.11:37: AAThey were stoned, they were sawed in two, they were killed by the sword. They went around clothed in skins of sheep or goats—poor, persecuted, and mistreated.

Chapter 11.11:38: The world was not good enough for them! They wandered like refugees in the deserts and hills, living in caves and holes in the ground.

Chapter 11.11:39: What a record all of these have won by their faith! Yet they did not receive what God had promised,

Chapter 11.11:40: because God had decided on an even better plan for us. His purpose was that only in company with us would they be made perfect.
